Note quite sure what you meant by minimizing a matrix t in your example.
I do agree that it would be great to support gradient on tf.diag.
If you want to optimize for matrix trace, there's a workaround as follows.

import tensorflow as tf
import numpy as np

with tf.Graph().as_default():
    Y = np.random.rand(3,3).astype(np.float32)
    X = tf.Variable(np.random.rand(3,3).astype(np.float32))
    Z = tf.matmul(X,Y)

    ones = np.ones(3).astype(np.float32) 
    eye = tf.diag(ones)
    loss = tf.reduce_sum(tf.mul(Z, eye))
    optimizer = tf.train.AdagradOptimizer(0.01).minimize(loss)
    sess = tf.Session()
    sess.run(tf.initialize_all_variables())
    with sess.as_default():
        for i in range(100):
            sess.run(optimizer)
            print sess.run(loss)
            print X.eval()

body:
Note quite sure what you meant by minimizing a matrix `t` in your example.
I do agree that it would be great to support gradient on tf.diag.
If you want to optimize for matrix trace, there's a workaround as follows.

```
import tensorflow as tf
import numpy as np

with tf.Graph().as_default():
    Y = np.random.rand(3,3).astype(np.float32)
    X = tf.Variable(np.random.rand(3,3).astype(np.float32))
    Z = tf.matmul(X,Y)

    ones = np.ones(3).astype(np.float32) 
    eye = tf.diag(ones)
    loss = tf.reduce_sum(tf.mul(Z, eye))
    optimizer = tf.train.AdagradOptimizer(0.01).minimize(loss)
    sess = tf.Session()
    sess.run(tf.initialize_all_variables())
    with sess.as_default():
        for i in range(100):
            sess.run(optimizer)
            print sess.run(loss)
            print X.eval()
```
